question: How is the movement of Tom Ditamus ultimately associated with the Ohio river?
gold_answer: Tom Ditamus moved to the Ohio river.
llm_answer:
Tom Ditamus’s entire westward movement is inseparable from the Ohio River.  
He first came out of the Cumberland backwoods by descending the Kentucky River and ascending the Ohio to the mouth of the Kentucky—Port William—where he settled. After his wife died and his land-title failed, he left that very cabin and again “moved to the Ohio river,” i.e., he relocated his family to the river-front settlement. Finally, when he agreed to spirit Suza Fairfield away, he started the return journey in a wagon from that same Ohio-river landing. Thus every stage of Tom’s wandering—arrival, residence, departure, and the hired trip with Suza—is tied to the Ohio River.
